column1: Portage is a city in and the county seat of Columbia County
column4: 662 at the 2010 census making it the largest city in Columbia County. The city is part of the Madison Metropolitan Statistical Area.

column1: Portage was named for the Fox-Wisconsin Waterway
column2: a portage between the Fox River and the Wisconsin River
column3: which was recognized by Jacques Marquette and Louis Joliet during their discovery of a route to the Mississippi River in 1673. The city's slogan is "Where the North Begins."

column1: The Native American tribes that once lived here
column2: and later the European traders and settlers
column3: took advantage of the lowlands between the Fox and Wisconsin Rivers as a natural "portage". This is reflected in indigenous names for the town
column4: such as the Menominee name Kahkāmohnakaneh
column5: which means "at the short cut". In May 1673
column6: Jacques Marquette joined the expedition of Louis Jolliet
column8: to find the Mississippi River. They departed from St. Ignace on May 17
column9: with two canoes and five voyageurs of French-Indian ancestry (Métis). They followed Lake Michigan to Green Bay and up the Fox River
column10: nearly to its headwaters. From there
column11: they were told to portage their canoes a distance of slightly less than two miles through marsh and oak plains to the Wisconsin River. Later
column12: French fur traders described the place as "le portage"
column13: which eventually lent itself to the name of the community. As a portage
column14: this community developed as a center of commerce and trade; later
column15: a canal was constructed to facilitate this trade. When the railroads came through
column16: the community continued in this role.

column1: Portage emerged at this place because of its unique position along the one and a half mile strip of marshy floodplain between the Fox and Wisconsin Rivers. By the end of the 17th century
column4: served as the major fur trade thoroughfare between Green Bay and Prairie du Chien. It was not until the 1780s and 1790s that traders built their posts and warehouses at each end of The Portage.  In the early 19th century Portage was primarily populated by Métis.  In 1828
column5: the federal government recognized the strategic economic importance of The Portage and built Fort Winnebago at the Fox River end. After 15 years of controversy
column6: Winnebago settlement (now Portage) won the county seat in 1851.  The community incorporated as Portage City in 1854.

column1: The Portage business district lies along a hill that overlooks the Portage Canal. The buildings now in the city's downtown were once part of a bustling
column2: urban commercial center serving a large region across north central Wisconsin. The building of the city paralleled its commercial prominence between the end of the American Civil War and the second decade of the 20th century.

Portage lies in the Wisconsin River valley. The city is surrounded by prairies and grasslands. Approximately three miles (5 km) west of the city are the Baraboo bluffs.  According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has a total area of 9.62 square miles (24.92 km2)
column4: 8.82 square miles (22.84 km2) is land and 0.80 square miles (2.07 km2) is water. The location of the town at the split of the Wisconsin and Fox river is what gives it the name "Portage"
column5: which means carrying a boat of its cargo between two navigable waters. In addition to the rivers
column6: the city has access to Swan Lake and Silver Lake.

column2: the streets were laid out on a traditional grid system. Today
column3: the streets of the outlying city are contorted as a result of the many marshes and lowlands that run through much of Columbia County. The northern side of the city thus looks different from the central city
column4: with the organized grid street system giving way to a more suburban streetscape with a lower housing density.

column1: The city has two commercial areas. One is the downtown historic district
column2: which features several small boutique shops and restaurants; the other is the Northridge commercial area that features big box stores. In the summer of 2007
column3: the Portage Canal was cleaned up and now features a bike path that runs alongside part of it. In the summer of 2008
column4: the main downtown street was redone. Historical landmarks of the city include the Museum at the Portage

column1: Portage Community School District serves Portage.
Portage High School (Wisconsin) was recently upgraded to a larger building
column2: with the older high school building now housing the Wayne E. Bartels Middle School. Portage has three elementary schools: John Muir
column4: and Rusch. Three rural elementary schools serve three of the towns in Columbia County: Lewiston
column6: and Caledonia. There are also two private schools: St. John's Lutheran and St. Mary's Catholic Schools. The Madison Area Technical College
column7: also has a campus located in Portage.

column1: Wisconsin Department of Corrections operates the Columbia Correctional Institution.

column5: giving the city a 30-minute commute to Madison and 15-minute commute to Wisconsin Dells. The city also lies only a few hours from Milwaukee

column1: Portage is served by Amtrak's Empire Builder between Chicago and Seattle or Portland
column2: with a train stopping there in each direction every day.

column1: Portage is served by intercity bus from Milwaukee via Madison and to Wisconsin Rapids via Stevens Point
column2: with a bus stopping in each direction daily at the Portage station.

column1: Portage Municipal Airport (C47) serves the city and surrounding communities.
